Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 11:37AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Mary - I've been considering your post since last night and trying to devise a reply that will make sense.  I will try to be organized in my answer and not ramble.  lol I definitely think you are grieving the loss of your former life.  We have a lot of loss as a result of our cancer dx, in general, and even more with our mets dx.  I don't know if we ever get over that loss.  I think we experience it even more when we're doing harsh treatments and feeling like shit.  It's perfectly normal to grieve that loss and is probably even more intense because you're young & "should" be healthy and active.   I agree with what you said about having a child/children may help some of us do everything we can to survive.  I remember wanting to quit chemo many times, and sobbing the nights before my tx's, but looking at my very young children and knowing I had to do it anyway.  I don't know why my will to live wouldn't be as strong if it weren't for them.  I've always figured that I wouldn't be one of the ones to survive a major catastrophe, otherwise.  lol  As for a bucket list, I've never had one and my dx hasn't changed that.  If I had unlimited funds, perhaps, I would have a few things on my list, but I think I'm mostly content with what I've been able to do & see.  I tend to make the most of where I live (not far from you, actually) and realize that I already live near some of the most amazing places on earth and feel very fortunate for that. So, for me, a buck list wouldn't be motivation to try to live until I achieve them.  I do, however, have certain activities I would like to do with my children before it's too late, so I guess I have a "mommy" list. I have different "states", too.  I think they are: ignore, reality, optimism.  I can ignore my situation when I need to function on a day-to-day basis.  My children help me with this because they are so egocentric.  When they aren't around, I can use distractions to keep me in my "ignore" state.  Keeping busy by volunteering at their school, cleaning house, playing video games, reading, etc. help.  My "reality" state can go in one of two different directions.  There's the 'I need to prepare myself and my family for my eventual demise so I had better plan ahead and get busy' form, or the 'this totally sucks and is so unfair, why is this happening to me, am I going to die soon?' form.  I'm not fond of either form of the "reality" state.  Then, there's the "optimism" state which is my favorite.  I can acknowledge that I have cancer, but I feel it's going to be okay because a tx will come along that will help me live at least long enough to get my children old enough that I feel okay leaving them.  It's my favorite because I don't have to ignore my situation totally so it kind of feels more true.  And, it could come to pass.  No one really knows what the future holds.   I also have a couple of general coping mechanisms which I've had since my original dx. which are: there's always someone worse off than I and remember to take it day by day or even minute by minute, if necessary.  My latest coping mechanism is: "It is what it is".  It works for a lot of different situations and helps me to accept what is and deal with it with less emotion.  It reminds me that I don't need to judge everything to just put one foot in front of the other and move forward. Mary, I hope you can find something that helps you get up each morning, and look forward to your day. Sometimes, mine is as simple as my first cup of coffee in the morning.  Try to notice in your life whatever makes you happy or even content, no matter how small, or silly, and work to make that happen more often.  When I'm in a particularly awful "reality" state, I use "Damn You, Autocorrect!" because it never fails to make me laugh.  Hang in there, and best wishes for feeling better and finding a tx that works.  Cynthia

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2012 10:19PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I had my last "real" period right around my very first chemo, then I went into chemopause (I had 8 chemo txs so I'm not sure if that makes a difference).  About a year later, while on Tamoxifen, I had some light spotting for a couple of days.  I had my hormone levels checked and I was still considered menopausal.  I felt as if I would start my period for a good couple of years after tx, but except for the one time spotting, I never did.  I eventually entered "official" menopause as opposed to chemopause.  Depending on your age, it is possible to begin menstruating again.  Tamoxifen will not usually prevent this.  If you feel the bleeding isn't menstrual related, it would be a good idea to get it checked out because Tamoxifen can affect the uterus.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 11:00PM Cynthia1962 wrote: My 7 year old (2nd grade, too) lies a lot.  It drives me crazy.  I think it's partly his age.  He just doesn't want to get in trouble for what he did and I think he also feels badly for his behavior.  I have not come right out and told him that I'm going to die, but he knows that people die of cancer.  He is very sensitive and I'm letting him take the lead, so I don't think his lying is a result of my cancer.  On the other hand, since I began IV chemo a few months ago, he and his sister have been meaner to each other.  I attribute it to the greater stress in our home due to my fatigue and pain.  I just have no patience because everything takes so much energy.  My son was having issues being away from me at school and the staff had allowed him to help in the office before school to distract him and help him feel useful.  It almost always involved him crying and clinging to me.  Most of the other moms who knew and some of the staff thought it was because of my cancer.  His teacher finally said enough was enough and told him it was time for me to drop him off in the roundabout because he was a big boy now.  She waited for us to show up each morning for a week and helped him out of the car and took his mind off me driving away.  She gradually backed away until he was eventually getting out on his own without her nearby.  He still "misses" me, but it's no longer an issue.  It wasn't about the cancer at all which is what I suspected all along.  It's so hard to know what is going on with them.  I hope things improve for your son.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 08:00PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I'm back.  Sorry I didn't post sooner, but I mostly slept yesterday when I got home from the hospital, and today has just been crazy.  My surgery went wonderfully.  I couldn't have asked for better.  I really like how I was treated at the hospital.  They were very warm, friendly and caring.  When I mentioned that I had a terrible headache which was causing me to be nauseous while waiting for my surgery, the nurse found a anesthesiologist to give me meds.  He was so considerate.  I had a different anesthesiologist for my surgery who was a hoot.  He helped me feel calmer because I hate being put under.  My surgeon talked with me before about what port I wanted and he said they did have a power port if I wanted one.  I decided to go with the regular and asked for the smallest one they had so I got a mini Vaxcel.  It's supposed to have a small profile so I hope it doesn't stick out as much as my last one.  Oh, and he did get it in the same side.  Woot! I can'twait to see it when I can take the bandage off tomorrow. I have had minimal pain.  I was so amazed when I could move my arm and even lift it some right after surgery.  It was so different than last time.  I took a Darvocet when I got home just to be safe, but I've only used Advil since then.  It just feels sore and kind of achy.  Not bad at all.  I'm so relieved.  I felt comfortable being home alone with the kids today and all went well.  Unlike yesterday, when they took advantage of Grandma and convinced her they were allowed to do things they aren't.  Then, my daughter caused the toilet to overflow, too.  My poor Mom!!! Thanks everyone for all your help and encouragement.  It was kind of emotional getting a port again, especially one I'll always have, but I just refused to think about it and focused on the benefit I'll get.  And, both my nurse and surgeon say my veins will improve now with less use.  So, that will be nice for blood draws since I go to a lab for those. It's great going into a new situation armed with all the knowledge and experience I get from you women here.  I mention you a lot to doctors and nurses because I get most of my info from here.  I love how we help each other out!  It's nice to not feel alone. Cynthia

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 06:58PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I was dx'd with mets in my hip only Nov. '10 and was switched from Tamoxifen to Arimidex and began Aredia.  Last month, a bone scan showed progression of mets to my rt clavical and groin area.  My onc switched me to Faslodex.  It's my understanding that each new treatment may stop or slow progression, but only temporarily until the cancer adapts and defeats the medication.  Your onc will keep trying different treatment options with you to slow or stop your progression as long as possible.  I know it doesn't feel like it, but we are lucky that there are so many medications that work for bone mets.  Hang in there and I hope you have good results with your next treatment protocol. Cynthia

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 05:01PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Unfortunately, genetic testing only covers a few known genetic causes of breast cancer.   Since there seems to be a significant amount of BC on your father's side of the family, you should probably be watched more closely.  It also matters at what age the women on both sides of your family had breast cancer.  The younger they were, the more significant it is.  It's scary finding this out, but it's better to know, than to not know.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 05:08PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Basil, Sorry you've had to join our club.  Here is my story: I felt lump, saw gyn, he did fna to make sure it wasn't a cyst.  He then referred me for a mammo, u/s, and surgery consult.  I had digital mammo & u/s, then carried the films to my surgical consult appt.  Surgeon looked at films, then did her own u/s right then, and declared the lump was probably b9 but needed to come out.  I had an excisional bx, and she gave me the results in person a week later.  In the meantime, I got the mammo & u/s results which said it looked b9, to come back in 6 months.  I'm so glad I was already scheduled for surgery or I might have waited.  After my surgeon gave me the bc results, she gave me the choice of 3 oncologists and discussed each one with me, then I picked one.  Later, we discovered that he didn't take my insurance, so I saw a different one on the list and am really pleased with him. I recently saw my gyn again for a consult on the Tamoxifen tx and how much I'll be screen.  You need to find yourself a caring and competent gyn to help you through this.  Good luck on your search for a surgeon.  If possible, try to get one that specializes in breast cancer or does a lot of those surgeries.   A good gyn should know of one and many practices also list their expertise on their websites. Wishing you all the best, Cynthia

Posts.Content: May 30, 2011 07:07PM Cynthia1962 wrote: My husband told his family and coworkers while I was still waiting for test results so they found out pretty quick that my cancer had come back.  I waited to tell my parents because it was almost Thanksgiving and I didn't want to ruin it, but they asked me about my test results and I had to tell them.  Except for my best friend, I held off telling most of my friends for a few months and still have a few I haven't told.  I waited a few months to tell my daughter, but I haven't told my son because he would only hear that his mother is going to die and it would crush him.  I told one of my neighbors because her daughter (who is older than mine) plays with my daughter and would need to understand what she was going through.  I think she told another neighbor because this woman used to be my mortal enemy and now she's nice as pie to me.  LOL  Whatever works, I guess.  I still hate her, but it's lead to less stress in the neighborhood for my kids. At first, I told my daughter's educational coordinator at the charter school we homeschooled through, but no one else there.  She didn't really understand and eventually asked me what my prognosis was.  She was shocked when I told her.  Eventually, I met with a few other people at the school to go over some test results concerning some learning issues my dd was having and I vaguely shared what was going on and why we wouldn't be homeschooling next year.  I later learned that the secretary that sits outside the director's office heard what I said and asked my friend about it.  So, far, she's the only person that looks at me with pity.  Everyone else treats me as if nothing has changed.  I plan to eventually tell my kids' new teachers at the new school, but I'm gonna wait until it matters.  Right now, I'm doing great except for a few down days due to Aredia or Arimidex.  I'm never sure what causes what.   And, of course, my irl support group knows.  Other than that, I pretty much keep it to myself and life goes on.  Eventually, it'll be more obvious that I'm ill and then I'll share.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 06:01PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I'm sorry to hear you're having such difficulty with the Neulasta.  I didn't have Neulasta, but multiple injections of Neupogen instead.  While I never ended up in the hospital, the back spasms brought on by the Neupogen literally would bring me to my knees.  Very painful, not to mention embarrassing.  I lived on Darvocet the week of those injections until the spasms passed.  I also had heart palpitations which my onc's nurse said were "normal".  I eventually figured out that they were caused by the chemo giving me reflux which I couldn't feel.  My heart has a tendency to "overreact" to everything and reflux is one of those things. Reflux can also make it seem as if you can't breathe, too.  So, maybe, this could the situation for you.  Try Pepcid or another med for reflux and see if it helps.  Also, I was told to take Claritin or Benedryl to help with the side effects of the Neupogen so I imagine they would help with Neulasta, too.  Good luck and congrats on finishing your first chemo! Cynthia

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 05:41PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Wow, Leah...I just read your post.  That is so scary.  Who would expect a sudden reaction at the 4th infusion?  I'm glad that slowing the infusion helps.  I don't tend to have allergic reactions to meds, fortunately, but I did react to Taxotere.  During the first tx, I had a funny sensation after the first 20 mins or so, but by the time I looked around for the nurse, it had passed.  The next time, it happened again, but I just waited for it to pass and it did, but it took longer.  Same thing happened with the 3rd tx and it lasted even longer so I got ready to flag down the nurse, but it stopped.  Right before the 4th and last tx, I told the nurse what had been happening and she froze in her tracks.  lol  She loaded me up with more antihistamine and started the drip even slower.  Sure enough, I had a reaction and this one was worse than the others, but it came on much later than before.  She stopped the drip, the dr came in, they gave me a bunch of meds and I insisted I wanted to try again.  So, we did, but I couldn't get past the reaction so the dr decided that I'd had enough and it wouldn't be an issue.  I guess I can't have Taxotere anymore.  :( If I remember right, I think they used to slow the AC drip down for me, too.  It used to give me a terrible headache.  We finally figured out at the last tx, that I needed a lot of hydration to prevent the headache.   I'm so glad your tx's are working!  How exciting.  My onc doesn't do scans very often so I only know by my tumor markers that I'm responding to the Arimidex, but I'll take it.  lol   Cynthia

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 08:33AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Formygirls - I'm sorry to hear you have one more thing on your plate.  As if we don't have enough to deal with.  I had gd with my last pregnancy, and it's always in the back of my mind that I'm at increased risk for diabetes now.  I learned that I have asthma a month after learning I had mets.  I wasn't sure which scared me more.  Then, I realized that if I control my asthma, I won't live long enough for it to be a problem.  A very sobering thought, as you well know.  As for trouble taking in protein, have you tried protein shakes?  I use Muscle Milk.  Two scoops (in water) gives you 32g protein, 18g carbs, & 5g fiber.  I add it milk instead of water so I get added protein and calories.  How about soy?  Can you eat that?  There are chemo cookbooks that have lots of good ideas and recipes for increasing calories and protein.  For instance, you can add more milk and butter to mashed potatoes.  What about cheese and/or beans?  Bean and cheese burritos are a good idea.  Or just cheese sticks/blocks.  How about nuts?  Eating some sort of protein with your fruit will help the fruit sugar be assorbed at a slower rate.  You could blend tofu, nuts, protein powder, and milk in with your fruit smoothies to make it more a meal. I'm sure someone with more experience will answer your post.  I'm sorry I couldn't be more help.  Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 02:44AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Well, chemo put me into permanent menopause so removing my ovaries wouldn't have added any benefit.  And, the ovaries aren't the only source of estrogen, either.  So, I think it depends on each woman's situation: is she at risk of osteoporosis, heart disease, recurrence?  What is her age at dx?  All these factors and more must be considered so it isn't as easy as saying the benefit of removing one's ovaries is definitely worth it over the risks.  For instance, studies are showing a slight benefit of AI's vs Tamoxifen for preventing recurrence, but women who were on AI's the full 5 years or longer vs women who spent some of those yrs on Tamoxifen were not living longer because the risks of AI's were mitigating the benefits of preventing recurrence.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2012 04:35PM Cynthia1962 wrote: wrsmith2x - I never had a local recurrance.  zsterling - my bone mets were discovered after my tumor markers (CEA and CA 15-3) went up.  I wasn't experiencing any pain yet, but did shortly after this.  My onc confirmed with a bone scan.  An x-ray didn't show the mets yet.  The pain did not feel like a sore spot. Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 01:04PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Jenlee - I was rereading your earlier post about hoping that if mets are discovered early, spread can be prevented.  Unfortunately, this isn't how mets work and they WILL spread.  It's what they do and why they got out of the breast in the first place.  How fast they spread and where they spread is determined by your treatment and response to such and the pathology of your cancer.  But, eventually, all mets adapt to your tx and you have to change it until there aren't any more txs to try or your body can no longer handle the txs.  This is why early stage bc is a completely different ballgame from advanced breast cancer.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 03:11AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Information from Dr. Susan Love regarding screening for metastatic disease.  What she basically says is this: Unlike primary cancers, recurrent cancers do not have a better prognosis when they are detected early. Many doctors still do blood tests every three to six months. This may include a blood count (CBC) as well as CEA, CA 15-3, CA 27.29, and liver blood tests. Many patients and physicians assume that using these tests to find metastases early improves outcomes. Unfortunately, we have lots of data that this is not true. This also holds true for the routine use of bone scans, chest X-rays, and CAT scans. This doesn't mean that we as individuals won't think finding our mets earlier isn't beneficial to us in some way.  I'm glad mine was found early because it gives me more time to prepare myself and my family while I'm still feeling relatively well.  It just means that it may not make a difference in overall prognosis.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 11:10AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Jenlee - Research appears to be indicating that the genetics of our tumor determines not only whether we will have a recurrence, but when we will (early or late) and how well it will respond to treatment.  So, some of us will reach NED for many years and some of us may not reach it at all and there isn't a whole lot that can be done to change that including catching it "early".  I hope that over time you can accept this uncertainty and live your life as if you'll stay cancer-free because, in all liklihood, you will.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 07:13AM Cynthia1962 wrote: Baldeagle - Not to confuse the issue further, but tumor markers are reliable for 80% of women.  For those of us for whom it is effective, it's a good way to have an idea if treatment is working or not without having to get a lot of scans or wait for a symptom.  It's why I only get bone scans every 6 months unless we know by my tumor markers and symptoms that a tx isn't working and we want to have an idea of what the mets are doing.  It's just one more possible tool in an onc's arsenal.  In my opinion, to throw it away because it isn't effective in a minority of women without even seeing if a patient is in that minority is irresponsible. Good luck tomorrow!  I hope you get some answers.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 07:39PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I lost weight during chemo for my initial dx of bc, but put some back on when treatment was done.  My onc was concerned that I was still underweight, though, but it's what I had weighed for years so I knew it was normal for me.  Then, Tamoxifen really killed my appetite and I lost weight again and really struggled to keep my weight up.  When I was put on Arimidex for mets, my appetite improved but my weight stayed the same even though Arimidex really gave me a belly.  Then, Faslodex didn't make much difference, but Megace - look out.  It definitely increased my appetite and I put on at least 10 lbs which thrilled my onc to no end.  The weight stayed on for awhile even after I was switched to Xeloda, but once I managed to get the Xeloda bloating under control, I lost a few pounds.  So, I got bc even though I was "underweight" and had a recurrence as well.  I find it interesting that all the women in my support group who have had a recurrence are thin as well.  As some others have said, we're all individuals with our own genetics that determines what diseases we get and why.  Since the horse has already fled the barn, I figure it's too late to worry about what might have opened the barn door.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 01:38PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Laurie - I really sympathize.  I also have a 10 yo daughter.  She was 4 when I was orginally dx'd, then 8 when it came back to my bones.  I have been very honest with her about my situation, but I know she can handle it.  It gives us the chance to talk about her future and I what I want her to know.  It allows me to "speed-up" the sharing of info I think she needs to have.  It lets us discuss what the future might be like with just her dad and brother.  But, my daughter is a "thinker" and she wants to know things.  She began asking me "deep" questions at a young age, so I knew she could handle this.  Her little brother, age 7, is a completely different story.  All he knows is that I have cancer and am taking chemo.  He is not concerned about it because I've had cancer for practically his whole life and it's never occurred to him that it could end my life.  He's much less observant about such things and more concerned with subjects/things that interest him.  He's also more sensitive than his sister so it's been better that he hasn't figured things out yet until he has some more maturity.  So, I guess my point is that you know your daughter best.  And, sometimes, it's easier to share the reality of our situation when we're not put on the spot and we have time to really discuss/answer all their concerns and questions. Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 05:02PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I'm so sorry you're having to deal with this.  What a frustrating place to be.  I also found my lump while nursing my baby.  It sounds to me, if I'm reading your posts correctly, that you've only had TMs done when you were initially diagnosed and during treatment.  Do you know if you had them done right after your surgery as well?  The reason I ask is that mine were high when I was diagnosed, but dropped dramatically after my surgery when basically all the cancer was removed.  Then, my TMs weren't checked again during tx.  I think it was 3 to 6 months after the end of radiation before they were checked again.  Since they were still low, it meant they were probably reliable for me.  It may be too soon to know if your TMs will be reliable for you.  I think you are right to take a step back and give it some time.  You're taking Tamoxifen so you're where you should be in that respect.  Plus, it needs some time to build up in your system.  I agree that having another scan in a few months may be one way to see if the nodules have changed.  I'm sure others will add their experiences to this discussion, too.  Have you considered getting a second opinion?  Please continue to let us know how it goes for you.  And, congrats on your baby daughter.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 12:12AM Cynthia1962 wrote: I'm sorry you're having to deal with this.  I'm wondering if you were given a mammogram?  It can sometimes be difficult to see lumps in dense breasts with a mammogram, but it would be worth a try.  I was nursing when I had my mammogram and it was very doable.  Then, if the radiologist doesn't know what he is seeing or can't see anything or you are still wanting a better opinion, then a breast surgeon is the next step.  My surgeon looked at my mammo and u/s and told me we needed to remove the lump to know for sure what it was.  If you can feel a lump, then the radiologist should have persisted until he could tell you what he thinks it is or refer you to someone who can.  It sounds like he dropped the ball.  Hang in there and try not to worry.  There are a lot of things it can be, but it is important to persist until you know for sure what it is.   Cynthia

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2012 04:41AM Cynthia1962 wrote: kmwondering - I'm glad you're seeing a breast surgeon so quickly, and one that's both skilled and personable.  My surgeon was as well and it was a relief.  As for a mammogram while breastfeeding, it's very common for health professions to say certain procedures can't be done while nursing because they don't really know and they just pick the easiest thing for them.  Especially when nursing an older baby, it won't be a problem because you're probably producing less milk at this point.  I just nursed right before getting the mammo so my breasts would be as empty as possible and let the tech know I was lactating.  When it was determined that I needed to have the lump out, I nursed prior to the surgery to empty my breast, then after surgery I just nursed on the other breast to begin with, but by evening I was able to nurse on the breast that had the surgery.  My surgeon was very supportive of me continuing to nurse at that point and I didn't experience any issues as a result.  At the hospital, you may be told that you should pump and dump if you need to have an excisional bx because of the anesthesia, but they're just covering their butts.  It's not a problem, especially for older babies.  Good luck with everything and I hope it's one of the many B9 things it can be.   I'll be thinking of you and crossing my fingers it's nothing. Cynthia

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 03:17PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I am in the same boat.  I have a cavity under a crown on a tooth that had a root canal and my dentist says it can't be saved.  He has referred me to an oral surgeon, but he went on vacation so my appt. isn't for another week. My dentist says my options are to have it pulled or it can be sheered off at the gum line and a hole drilled in it to clean out the decay, then resealed.  He says that he only has one patient with ONJ and she had a lot of other issues with her teeth to begin with.  I checked with my onc and he wants me on 5 days of antibiotics before I get the tooth pulled and he said that if the bone around the tooth doesn't look like it's breaking down, then he isn't worried about ONJ.  Of course, according to the research I've read, there isn't a lot known about the exact cause of ONJ, so it's hard to know how to prevent it.  They do know that extractions increase the risk, but it can happen spontaneously, too.  It's possible that a common bacteria found in the mouth may be the culprit, too.  Listerine and baking soda are two things that kill this bacteria so it can't hurt to use them regularly.  If your tooth can't be saved in any other way, then you have no choice but to have it pulled.  Then, do everything you can to lessen the risk of ONJ.  Ask for antibiotics, use Listerine and either baking soda or a baking soda based toothpaste, and have the extraction done by an oral surgeon.  I know it's very scary when you think about the risk, but what choice do we have?  I just tell myself that the majority of women who've had extractions while on a bisphosphonate don't go on to develop ONJ.  It's actually a very rare side effect.  My chemo nurse says that my onc has had only 3 or 4 women with ONJ since he started prescribing bisphosphonates.  Plus, with so many woman being put on bisphosphonates now, researchers are finally make an effort to figure out how to prevent and treat ONJ.  Good luck and let us know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 12:23PM Cynthia1962 wrote: Tamoxifen is for any hormone positive woman regardless of whether she is pre or post menopausal.  It was the only antihomonal until the AI's came along.  I know many menopausal women on Tamoxifen so I think it depends of what is best for each woman's situation.  Some women are concerned about the bone loss with AI's or the joint pain, etc.  Some recent studies have shown that AI's are slightly more effective at preventing recurrence, but that benefit has to be weighed against the risk of bone loss and therefore fractures, etc.  Taking Tamoxifen for a few years and an AI for a few years had very good results probably because you got the benefit of the AI without so much of the risk.  It also seems to me that Tamoxifen is "easier" on women who are menopausal as far as uterine effects go.  And, while it does seem as if Tamoxifen suppresses menstruation, I haven't read anything that says it works that way, but it can make them irregular.  It's very reasonable to ask to have your hormone levels checked until you are sure you are menopausal, though, just so you have that information.   Good luck with the Tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 12:43AM Cynthia1962 wrote: MLM - The American Cancer Society has materials on talking to young children about a parent's cancer dx, and they also have a journal/coloring book that helps you talk with your child about how they feel and what's going to happen during your treatment.  If you call their 800 number, they'll send you these for free.  Everything that you're feeling is normal.  Who wouldn't be terrified?  Of course, it's all that you can think about and nights are definitely the worst.  This board saved me during the long nights in the beginning.  It's o.k. to ask your dr for something like Ativan to help you sleep.   I was very honest with my 5 year old daughter about what was happening. I told her I had bc, and that my drs were going to do everything they could to help me get better, but that I was going to be tired and sick and lose all my hair.  It gave her the opportunity to ask me questions and to tell me about her fears.  It also let me not have to be so strong in front of her because I felt like crying a lot and did.  I also bought a couple of books written for children of moms with bc and she would ask me to read them to her.  Sometimes, I couldn't get through them without crying, so my husband would take over. It was a year ago this month that I received my diagnosis, and I'm doing great.  My family and I made it through my treatments and it wasn't all bad and not nearly as horrid as I imagined it would be.  My children weren't traumatized and I think my daughter grew a lot from the experience.   Best wishes, Cynthia

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2011 07:09PM Cynthia1962 wrote: I was breastfeeding my second child when I was diagnosed, so I looked into the stats on it and breast cancer.  Here is some info I found by a well-known athropologist: www.kathydettwyler.org/detcanc...  There seem to be a lot of variables, so it's a difficult to be specific, but the benefit is greater the younger you are when you breastfeed and the longer you breastfeed.  If you were breastfed yourself, it also lowers your risk.  If I understand the info., you can half your risk by breastfeeding and having been breastfed.  Still, that won't be enough for many of us. Another thing I learned which I should have known, but didn't, is that doing things to lower one's risk isn't cummulative .  So, for instance, I breastfed two children for a total of 58 months, rarely drank liquor, didn't smoke, was a vegetarian, avoided known carcinogens, ate organic often, wasn't overweight, took supplements, etc., but these habits didn't combne to lower my risk to nothing.   Cynthia
